newsitem.title: USA: Parry says low US jobless rate linked to inflation.
newsitem.headline: Parry says low US jobless rate linked to inflation.

text.p: The U.S. unemployment is currently at a level that "generally" has been associated with rising inflation," Robert Parry, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, said Friday.
The Labor Department reported earlier that the jobless rate slid to 5.1 percent in August from 5.4 percent in July, while nonfarm payrolls grew by 250,000 in August.

Parry, who addressed a luncheon held as part of a joint meeting of Fed branch officials in the Northwest, was asked by a member of the audience his view of the likelihood of a recession sometime during the next four years.
He replied that, barring any unforeseen external shocks, it was unlikely provided the Fed pursues the correct policies to keep the economy on a steady course.
Describing the policies the Fed should pursue, Parry said, "We've got to make sure that this economy doesn't grow too fast or too slow."

He added, "If it grows much too slow you are in a recession. If it grows much too fast -- as we learned very painfully in periods in the late '60s and '70s and even to some exent a little bit in the '80s -- you cause inflationary pressures that cause the Fed to have to step on the brake hard."
